In the "The Problem" section, the opacity problem is introduced as the main issue where knowledge exists but isn't perceptible. The text mentions that the problem is structural, not storage-related. It connects to the idea that the structure is in the artifact but not in the creator's head. That might relate to working memory and cognitive load.

Moving to "The Cognitive Mechanism," it talks about Sweller's cognitive load theory, which is about working memory limitations. The text says that when information density outpaces comprehension, the excess becomes invisible. This seems to link cognitive load and working memory to the opacity problem. Also, Kirschner et al. mention distributing load across collaborators, time, or external representations. Since the opacity problem occurs when none of these are available, that connects to external structural representations as a solution.

In "AI Makes It Acute," vibe-coding is discussed as a scenario where developers use AI without fully understanding the code. This relates to material disengagement. The interaction pattern with AI adds interruptions, which ties into cognitive load and Mark et al.'s work on interrupted work. Also, AI-assisted composition is mentioned as part of the problem.

The "Why Better Prompting Won't Fix It" section states that even with better AI interaction, the problem remains because the structure exceeds working memory capacity. So, the opacity problem is about information density, not interaction quality. This reinforces the link between cognitive load, working memory, and the opacity problem.

In "The Remedy: External Structural Representations," the solution is presented as external structural representations. Endsley's situation awareness is mentioned as eroding in information-dense composition. The text connects external structural representations to epistemic actions (Kirsh and Maglio), which are actions that make mental computation easier. Also, Scaife and Rogers' mechanisms: computational offloading, re-representation, and graphical constraining are discussed. Larkin and Simon's work on diagrams reducing cognitive load is another point. So, external structural representations are linked to computational offloading, re-representation, and situation awareness. Also, the text mentions that these representations are epistemic actions, which ties into the cognitive mechanisms.

The "A Caveat on Cognitive Offloading" section warns that cognitive offloading might reduce critical thinking, as per Gerlich and Klein and Klein's extended hollowed mind. However, a structural tool that externalizes awareness while preserving interpretation might avoid this. This connects cognitive offloading to the critique of tools that outsource reasoning, and the knowledge graph as a way to show connections.
